title: Alan Powell (politician)
text:
Alan Tinsley Powell (born November 10, 1951) is an American politician who has served in the <a href="Georgia%20House%20of%20Representatives">Georgia House of Representatives</a> since 1991. He was originally elected as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>, but switched to a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> in 2010, citing his <a href="conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservative</a> views.
Tenure.
He supported the <a href="Election%20Integrity%20Act%20of%202021">Election Integrity Act of 2021</a>, a Republican-supported law to restrict voting rights in Georgia. Among its many provisions, it would restrict where <a href="Ballot%20box">ballot drop boxes</a> can be located and when they can be accessed, require photo identification for <a href="absentee%20voting">absentee voting</a>, shift back the deadline to request an absentee ballot, limit <a href="early%20voting">early voting</a> hours, and prevent anyone other than poll workers from giving food and water to voters standing in lines. Most controversially, it would restrict early voting on Sundays, when <a href="Black%20church">Black churches</a> traditionally run "Souls to the Polls" <a href="Get%20out%20the%20vote">get-out-the-vote</a> efforts. Powell defended the bill, saying "Show me the suppression. There is no suppression in this bill." The legislation was passed by the Republican-controlled legislature in Georgia shortly after the <a href="2020%20Georgia%20elections">2020 elections</a> when Democrats won the two U.S. Senate seats in Georgia and <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a> became the first Democratic presidential candidate to win Georgia since <a href="1992%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Georgia">1992</a>. Then-President <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a> and his allies made false claims of fraud in multiple states, including Georgia, after they lost the elections.
